image.altText: A close-up of a man with dark hair and blue eyes.

props.synopsis: After a month-long trial, Matt Wright was last week found guilty on two counts of attempting to pervert the course of justice by a Supreme Court jury. So, what's next in the case of the celebrity crocodile wrangler?

title.children: Could Matt Wright go to jail? What may happen next in the Netflix star's case

image.altText: a medium close up shot of a woman smiling at the camera with her hair up and a black and yellow tshirt on.

props.synopsis: Helen Lemach says her job is about building relationships and trust as much as telling people what they can do to change their lifestyles.Â

title.children: Diabetes educator wins national award for fighting 'silent killer'

image.altText: An aerial view of Alice Springs by night.

props.synopsis: The family of an Aboriginal man who died after being put in a "bear hug" is suing his Alice Springs disability care provider for negligence.

title.children: Aboriginal man died after carer put him in 'bear hug', family claims

image.altText: A man and a woman in running gear stand in front of an Aboriginal flag smiling.

props.synopsis: Charlie Maher has become the first Indigenous man to complete all seven major marathons in the world.

title.children: Indigenous runner grateful for historic world marathon feat

image.altText: A large LNG tank sits among mangrove trees, Darwin's skyline is visible in the background

props.synopsis: Documents reveal the scale of carbon pollution leaking from a Darwin LNG tank was like adding 8,300 new cars to the road every year. It is about to be filled again.

title.children: 'Huge' leak from gas plant kept secret from public in 'national scandal'

image.altText: An aerial view of the town of Katherine, showing the main street and the roofs of businesses and houses.

props.synopsis: Police say a woman has died of a suspected snake bite in the regional Northern Territory town of Katherine after she collapsed on Monday afternoon and was unable to be revived by paramedics.

title.children: Woman dies of suspected snake bite after collapsing at NT business

image.altText: A man kneels behind a white rhino calf.

props.synopsis: Peter Trembath, the subject of the 1990s documentary The Flying Vet, is calling time on a long and adventurous career.

title.children: Once paid with a gold nugget, The Flying Vet calls time on 45-year career

image.altText: Alfreda Dunn in front of a pre paid power meter in Alice Springs

props.synopsis: Northern Territory public housing tenants struggle to keep the power on amid calls for the government-owned provider to reduce tariffs on prepaid electricity.Â

title.children: Prepaid electricity customers struggle to keep the power on

image.altText: A close-up of man's hand holding a canister labelled as "pepper spray" in each hand. A couple of other bottles on the table.

props.synopsis: From Monday, September 1, Northern Territory residents can buy and use pepper spray for personal protection in a 12-month trial by the NT government. Let's break down the rules.

title.children: Want to buy pepper spray in NT? Here's what you need to know

image.altText: a teenage boy looks at the camera wearing a cap and headphone. His mum stands at his side smiling at him lovingly.

props.synopsis: Special assistance schools are experiencing growing demand as traditional classrooms fall short of meeting the needs of neurodivergent students.

title.children: Neurodivergent students exit mainstream in droves amid school refusal crisis

image.altText: Snoop Dogg

props.synopsis: Andrew Dillon is not concerned by the negative publicity surrounding the league's decision to hire controversial American rapper Snoop Dogg for its grand final entertainment.

title.children: 'He'll do a great job': AFL boss unmoved by Snoop Dogg grand final blow back

image.altText: A middle-aged man in glasses sits indoors, near a man holding cash in his hand.

props.synopsis: A respected Queensland council worker suffered a career-ending psychiatric injury after the fake email, which referred to a Indigenous people as "dirty bastards", was tabled in parliament by an MP on an anti-corruption crusade.

title.children: Council ordered to pay millions over fabricated racist email

image.altText: A young boy crying next to three women sitting in outside next to a brick wall.

props.synopsis: The International Association of Genocide Scholars says signatories to the genocide convention, including Australia, should prevent arms sales to Israel and uphold international law.

title.children: Leading scholars say Israel committing genocide in Gaza

image.altText: A man smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: Journalists in Australia are among dozens of reporters who fear for their lives and those of family members after receiving death threats from the Iranian regime.Â

title.children: Iran threats spark fear that journalists 'could die on the streets of Melbourne'

image.altText: An image showing a middle-aged man staring down the barrel of the camera.

props.synopsis: A week on from a shooting in Victoria's north east that killed two police officers, the alleged gunman remains on the run.

title.children: Police reviewing 'remarkable' amount of new Dezi Freeman information

image.altText: A blonde, middle-aged woman wearing a purple jacket speaks into a mic

props.synopsis: A suspected Russian interference attack disabled GPS navigation services at a Bulgarian airport impacting a plane carrying European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, according to Britain's Financial Times.

title.children: EU chief Ursula von der Leyen's plane hit by alleged Russian GPS interference

image.altText: Anne Ruston in the Senate.

props.synopsis: The Coalition, Greens and independent senator David Pocock team up to pressure the government to bring forward 20,000 home support packages, after the government's promised release of 83,000 was pushed back from July to November.Â

title.children: Labor faces Senate showdown over home supports for older Australians

image.altText: An image of a phone screen with an image of a photo it snapped accompanied by a chunk of text

props.synopsis: Artificial intelligence is predicted to influence many sectors of work, and it is no longer a question of if, but how. Yet experts say the technology can also bring opportunities.

title.children: Here's what job sectors are most and least at risk from AI

image.altText: Woman holds her young son in a city street.

image.altText: A young boy smiling

props.synopsis: The heartbroken parents of Jack Davey, a Melbourne schoolboy killed by an out-of-control car, say their lives have been destroyed by the devastating crash.

image.altText: Fred Newman is sitting at a brown wooden table with his energy bill

props.synopsis:
The South Australian government informed the ACCC after global energy giant ENGIE admitted to incorrectly telling a customer that power prices are set by the government.

Â

props.synopsis: Here's what experts have to say about the origins and value of these popular personality types. Â

title.children: Type A or Type B? Why we love to categorise ourselves

image.altText: Aerial shot of large ship leaving port.

props.synopsis: Options for the new Spirit of Tasmania ship to "ease the housing crisis" in Scotland or accommodate "displaced residents" in California were passed over in favour of it being docked at a cost to Tasmanian taxpayers of around $600,000 a month, documents reveal.

image.altText: A sign in an ALDI store saying "we support Aussie farmers", full of vegetables.

image.altText: Tony Burke and David Adeang sit at a desk and sign documents.

title.children: Prime minister insists $408m deportation deal with Nauru not a 'secret'

image.altText: A police car.

props.synopsis: Emergency services found a man with gunshot wounds inside a crashed car in Epping. A woman also suffered life-threatening injuries in the crash.Â

title.children: Police investigate shooting and crash in Melbourne's north

image.altText: A stylised collage shows polaroid frames around photos of a young boy, and a young man at centre

props.synopsis: The ABC has obtained a voice recording of a WA police officer laughing about the suicide of an Aboriginal prisoner. It comes as new data shows the state has the highest rates of Indigenous deaths in custody in Australia.Â

title.children: Linton warned a police officer he was going to die, then when he did, she laughed

image.altText: Two men in suits shake hands and smile in front of two national flags

image.altText: A man looks at the camera with a serious expression.

title.children: This man has spoken to the Kremlin. He says Putin 'wants to keep war going'

image.altText: a closeup of blueberries

props.synopsis: Australians are eating so many berries that regulators are considering restricting the use of a widely used pesticide.

title.children: Surge in berry consumption prompts call for pesticide ban

image.altText: Shackled migrants deplane an aircraft as officials herd them down the stairs.

image.altText: Two men celebrate after scoring a try in an NRL match

title.children: Bulldogs add another attacking change on eve of NRL finals

image.altText: Photo of person smiling with mouth closed and head tilted, with dark hair across their face.

props.synopsis: At 51, Australian-born MÄori writer Anne-Marie Te Whiu found she finally had time to reflect on her life. The result is a powerful new poetry collection, Mettle; an expansive collection, which invites readers in.

title.children: 'Survival isn't enough': In new poetry collection, author asks readers to push further
